reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central optimism lever in section 3: that value-pluralist groups can often get near-best outcomes via partitioning/trade (the split-the-galaxies style examples). Undermining clean partitioning weakens (not demolishes) the essay’s pro-trade optimism, but the overall position also leans on non-partition trade, hybrid goods, and already flags major blockers (threats, power concentration, institutions), so centrality is moderate rather than maximal. The argument’s strength is moderate: security-dilemma externalities plausibly make simple partition Pareto-improvements rarer and can shrink bargaining sets, but the critique is largely qualitative/speculative (e.g., “superlinear” strategic depth, a sharp ‘threshold’ collapse) and doesn’t show this dominates across plausible post-AGI governance/commitment regimes; also, the essay’s own ‘threats’ and institutional doubts partially prefigure the worry. Correctness is fairly high because the underlying mechanism (security externalities/arms-race incentives under fragmentation) is well-grounded, though some strong quantitative phrasing is not established. The critique is clear and focused on one issue, with little fluff.
title: Security externalities make galaxy-partitioning unstable at scale
